title: Top-Down, Bottom-Up: How UserTesting Drove AI Adoption | with Michael Domanic, Head of AI

rawLines.text: Today I'm just curious. I'm joined by
Michael Dominic, head of generative AI
business strategy at user testing, the
world's leading ondemand human insights
platform. Michael leads the company's
internal AI transformation program,
embedding AI into workflows across every
function. He spent years building
conversational AI and now focuses on
making generative AI not just practical
but measurable. Today we'll explore how
he's doing that and what others can
learn from his hands-on experience
leading change at scale. Michael,
welcome to Just Curious. Thanks D. It's
great to be here.
You've worked across customer experience
strategy and now AI transformation. Tell
us a little bit about that journey that
brought you to leading AI transformation
at user testing.
Yeah. So I mean the journey actually
starts before I was actually at user
testing. I used to be a customer of user
testing. So uh during chatbot pipe cycle
1.0 which is what I call it. So that's
takes us to the period of like 2016 to
2019 2020. Um I was designing a lot of
conversational interface experiences. Um
in that era every brand wanted a
Facebook messenger chatbot.
um or later that became Slack bots,
Skype bots. The backdrop to all of that
was conversational interface was
proliferating in homes across America
via Alexa and Google Assistant and
Google Home. So I actually used to work
um with companies designing those
experiences and used to test it at user
testing. Joined user testing. have had a
lot of different roles in the
organization. And in November of 2022
when OpenAI launched, you know,
Transformer 3.5, like that felt to me
like we were kind of going back to that
moment that I was in before user
testing, albeit with much better
technology. So, it just really felt like
the time for our company to wrap our
arms around this, embrace it. I had a
lot of support from leadership to really
push that mission forward.
Can you tell us a little bit more about
user testing and why is AI so important
to the future of the business? Yeah, so
user testing is a platform that our
customers use to create great
experiences for their customers, right?
So a lot of times our platform is
getting used by designers, by UX
researchers, but also by folks from
marketing that want to test, you know,
their marketing campaigns, copy, images,
you know, all that stuff. Um, and you
know, I think when it comes to AI at
user testing, there's two really
important ways that we use AI here. So,
one is the mission that I'm attached to,
which is to transform our organization,
transform the way that we work by
embracing AI capabilities. And the
second way that we really use AI is in
our product, right? So like we're
designing a lot of features within our
product that make make it easier for our
customers to use our product, enhance
the value that they get from our product
by leveraging AI capabilities. The thing
that I'm mostly focused on is the
internal transformation thing. That's is
that's super important for user testing
and I think it's important for any
company with a focus on knowledge work
because we know how much the current AI
capabilities can enhance the work that
you're doing, create amazing
efficiencies, help you create work
faster and really increase the strategy.
So we know that's a possibility user
testing. So we're really again wrapping
our arms around this and embracing those
capabilities.
Many companies struggle to move past
curiosity into implementation. What were
the first time? What were the first
signs rather at user testing that it was
time to invest in a true AI
transformation effort? Yeah, it's a
great question. You know, I mentioned
those two missions that we have to
embrace AI and user testing. One in our
product and you know, one to transform
the organization. I think for us early
on, we initially set out to integrate AI
into our product. We had already been
doing this right even before the
generative AI boom.
We've been building machine learning
homegrown machine learning models since
2019 and putting that in our product. So
again it just felt very natural to us
when this you know these generative AI
capabilities uh became available to
businesses to build upon that felt very
natural. Now the internal stuff we had
had a lot of conversations for probably
a period of about six to maybe 10 months
call it we had a lot of internal
conversations but like most
organizations we were trying to figure
out how does this integrate right like
how do how do we actually use this to
augment what we're doing um
I think in those early days for me it
was kind of crucial to focus in on a
specific use case and um the use case
that I focused on non on is a problem
that we dealt with and pretty much every
other company deals with and that's the
problem of information fragmentation. So
we have all of this information um that
gets disseminated across the
organization and it's in a lot of
different places. You know our sales
team uses highspot the rest of the
company uses Confluence. There's other
repositories of knowledge. I did an
internal study that looked at the cost
of the problem and we were just losing
way too much time because people were
just hunting through all of the
different resources, you know, knowledge
repositories that we have to find
answers to simple questions. So actually
what I did was in those early days is
created a custom GPT that pulled all
those knowledge resources together and
did another study that showed how much
of an improvement that was. And it was
really clear to us at that time that we
were saving a ton of time in you know
folks trying to find answers to
questions. We were also increasing the
access to knowledge for folks. So in
those early days that study that
experiment that we did made it really
clear what the possibility was
throughout the rest of the organization.
What internal challenges do you face
early on either culturally or
operationally and how did you start to
overcome them?
Yeah, I I think we kind of face both
challenges, both cultural and
operational. I think the the cultural
stuff is probably stuff that like every
organization was dealing with, continues
to deal with. I think a lot of that has
to do with people's trepidation about
this, you know, proliferation of AI. I
make it really clear to our organization
that I think the genie is out of the
bottle when it like that genie is not
going back in. I think we're all going
to get face this transformation sooner
or later, probably sooner than later.
And I think it's the responsibility of
any employer that considers themselves a
good employer to really uh lead their
organization through this
transformation, provide them with the
tools, the training um then enablement
to be able to take that that
transformation on. I think that's a
really important part of our mission and
again this is something I talk to our
organization about quite often. I think
operational challenges like this is a
we're asking people to change a lot of
their behavior, right? I think that's
what successful transformation looks
like when it comes to AI and that's a
hard thing to do. Changing changing
behavior is a really hard thing to do
for us. Once we decided that we were
going to make investments here, we chose
to use enterprise chatbt as our center
of gravity general purpose solution. Uh
we were deliberate about who we rolled
that out to in the early days. So it
wasn't full enterprise at that time. We
handpicked individuals who we knew were
going to be our early adopters who were
going to talk about the interesting
things that they were doing and that
like to be a pretty good strategy for us
because it created a little bit of
virality. Um it created a little bit of
FOMO for the individuals who didn't have
access. They were like you know why does
this person get access to this
transformational tool and I don't right.
So that that kind of helped us
um really like make this thing a little
bit viral within the company. Um, a few
months later we went, you know,
wall-to-wall enterprise. That was in the
summer of 2024.
And by that point, you know, a lot of
that interest had been built up in the
organization. So from an operational
standpoint, you know, a couple months
into our deployment, people a lot of
people in the organization felt like
they were ready to start experimenting.
Yeah. And when you picked those early
adopters, did you reach out to people
you thought had the potential to be kind
of early testers? Did you did you pick a
certain number of people within each
business or functional unit? What what
did that look like? Yeah, I think there
were a couple things. So, one is that
this conversation had already been
playing out in pockets of the
organization. So we were aware of where
that conversation was happening, who the
players were that were involved in that
conversation. You know, the these were
individuals who conveyed a specific like
specific interest in in doing this. So
that was kind of like one way that we
identified who those early adopters
were. Another way is very early on in
our chat GPT deployment, we were invited
to OpenAI to do a hackathon, a GPT
hackathon. And then again like we kind
of handpicked a larger set of
individuals to participate in that. And
again like that showed us who was really
leaning in, who who was really
interested in experimenting. So that was
another kind of wave of early adopters.
And then from that point
some you know awareness had kind of
spread in the organization some virality
had spread through the organization and
a lot of other people were saying like
hey like I've been reading a lot about
this I have my own personal account
maybe I've been using it for work maybe
I haven't not going to tell you right
but I would love to use it for work and
uh you know again that was like another
maybe another wave of that that those
early adopters and maybe by that point
enough of the organization had kind of
realized that people that I work with
are doing really interesting things. I
want to do those interesting things,
too. So, this interest kind of kept
compounding over time. You mentioned
virality. Were there any things that you
did to help facilitate virality and the
sharing of what people were doing within
the broader organization?
Yeah, we talked about this a lot in
those days. I mean we still do but you
know what we did was in lunch and learns
or at all hands meetings you know
anytime a large kind of cross-section of
the organization was getting together we
were talking about the things that the
early adopters were doing some of the
experiments that they were running some
of the you know those early days like
the GPTs that folks were creating so
yeah this was something that we talked
about to try to spread some of that
interest and and and that virality.
Yeah. In terms of how they were using
it, did you
shape that use at all with the early
adopters? Did you allow them to
freestyle based on how they were using
it already and maybe what problems they
saw it could be helpful to solving for
them? How did that how did that use kind
of manifest itself? I think it was both
things that you mentioned. you know, we
had spent a lot of time thinking about
what are the really interesting ways,
the meaningful ways that we could bring
this into our organization. Um, as we
identified those interesting use cases,
sure, we shared that out with our early
adopters and saying like, "Hey, try this
or try this." Folks were also doing a
lot of experiments, right? They were
figuring out other interesting things to
do with the tool. So, there was a lot of
knowledge sharing that helped other
people figure out like, hey, like this
person's doing this. I might not do that
exact thing, but that gives me an idea
over here. I think the genesis of this
is really to spur on that conversation
that was happening in places like a
dedicated slack channel. At that at that
point, it was like our AI exper
experimenters Slack channel. We were
getting together regularly as a group,
an early adopters group to, you know,
again have these conversations, talk
about the interesting things that we're
doing, the interesting things that we're
learning, how are the models changing,
how do those changes impact other things
that we might be able to do. Yeah. Uh
you mentioned that early adopters and
then I guess some of the later adopters
were actively experimenting. somewhere
building GBTs and sharing them with the
organization. Uh sounds like a very kind
of bottoms up effort. Uh was there a
top- down strategy that you then layered
on? Um and yeah, tell us a little bit
more about that. When did you decide to
um you know layer on a top down
strategy? What did it look like and how
did that play out? Yeah, I think I think
that top down strategy actually came
first. So in those again early days with
the top down strategy, the first thing
that was established here at user
testing was an AI working group, an AI
governance group where we had identified
what are the possibilities with these
tools, right? Like just a cross
functional group people, leaders from
around the organization having a
conversation about what are the what are
the possibilities here? What's the art
of the possible? Um then that quickly
turned into what are the security
implications? What are the legal
implications? Do we create an AI usage
guideline? Do we create an internal AI
manifesto about uh what do we do with
the tools? How do we use it? Why are we
doing this? So yes, I mean like that is
that is all stuff that was kind of
happening in the very very early days I
think before we even rolled out any
general purpose tools. Um and then once
we felt like we were ready to roll those
tools out because we had some basic
infrastructure in place um you know then
then that's when we kind of went out to
our early adopters and said you have
access to this tool now you know you're
one of our early adopters you're one of
our champions you know let's figure out
how how we use this.
What did that initial governance look
like and what was your approach to
balancing innovation and experimentation
with legal or ethical or security
concerns?
So yeah and like I said the early
governance was a cross functional group
of people. So people from legal
security, uh our CEO, our CTO, leaders
from product, leaders from engineering,
like basically like any part of the
organization that we felt like was going
to get impacted by this transformation
um had a seat at the table and still do
like that's still a group that exists
and we still meet on a very regular
basis. In those early days, it was super
important for us to figure out what are
those legal and security implications.
So the security implications pretty
obvious, right? if we're using this
tool, if we're putting sensitive data,
company data into this tool, is that
going to show up in the response of
somebody's prompt outside of our
company, right? Like we didn't want that
to get leaked. So, we worked with our
partners to make sure that we were
operating in an environment that our
data, our prompts, everything that we're
doing doesn't train the model. Think
obviously like that's really important
for probably most if not all businesses.
I think when we in those early days as
well, the other thing that's really
important was important for us to figure
out was you know there's people across
our organization that have access to all
sorts of sensitive data. What data is a
no-go for us? What data can we not use
in any AI context and what data can we
be more liberal about? User testing has
a I would say a relatively cautiously
liberal AI governance policy. There are
definitely classes of data that no one
can ever use in a context in context of
AI and a lot of that is our customer
data. So earlier talked about how our
customers use user testing. They capture
feedback on you know what it's
essentially what it's like to to be
their customer. Maybe they're designing
a new mobile application and they have a
Figma prototype. They're getting
feedback on that Figma prototype via our
platform. They own all of that, right?
Like our customers own all of that data.
very few people in the organization
would even have access to that data. And
for those that do, they know and I
remind them about this every single day.
No customer data could ever be used in
an AI context. Unless that's in our
product, unless we have agreements, you
know, with our customers, they invoke
it, right? Like that's something
separate. But when you're using LLMs on
a day-to-day basis, you're just never
going to use that data. There are other
like classes of data as well like PII,
obviously, like you don't want to use
that. Don't put your credit card in,
right? like don't put employee names and
addresses like stuff like that. But I
think every organization needs to figure
out what their data strategy is and make
sure that that gets clearly and
regularly communicated throughout the
company, right? You mentioned the
building of custom GPTs. I guess a first
step is identifying a use case or a
problem to solve. What do you look for
when you are looking for a good use case
for AI?
That is a great question. So that's not
always me making that decision. We have
fully democratized the building of
custom GPTs throughout the organization.
You know, we talk about this a lot in
the company. We create GPTs that are,
you know, intended to be used by
essentially everyone in the company. And
everyone in the company has the ability
to create them. They don't need to come
to me and say like, hey, like I want to
do this thing with custom GPTs. Is it
okay if I do this? Right? As long as it
fits into, you know, our governance
policies, like that's totally fine. Like
create create a custom GPT. I think like
the larger question might be what are
custom GPTs good at and like what what
should companies thinking about using
them for? I think like GPTs are really
great at any kind of repetitive workflow
that you might be doing. I'll give you
an example. Like I have a GPT that
analyzes our usage and adoption for all
of our AI tools, right? I get that from
the vendor. It's often like a massive
data dump that they give to me that I
have to like sift through, but I've
created a custom GPT that analyzes all
of that, spits out reports. I send those
reports to leaders in the organization.
They can see what their teams are doing,
right? Like that's a great use case for
a GPT. Um, and that's just it's just me
using that GPT. Yeah, other use cases uh
for GPTs that are, you know, used across
our organization is we have one that
creates OKRs for everyone in the
company. Um, you know, I don't want
anyone in our company to be like have to
spend the time to write really great
OKRs. Like, you shouldn't have to be
good at writing OKRs. That's a
distraction from the thing that you're
hired at. Like, if you're a salesperson,
you're hired because you're a great
salesperson, not because you're great at
writing OKRs, right? I want you have
great OKRs. like I want you to have like
a really awesome road map that m latters
to the larger goals of the organization
but you certainly don't need to be good
at creating them and that's what that
GBT does right that GBT is trained on
here are the large goals of the
organization here's our executive goals
senior leadership team you know middle
management and then individual
contributors so wherever you sit in the
organization the GPT already knows what
are the goals for essentially everyone
above you in this company tell us what
you're working on. Okay, here's a great
set of OKRs for you. You could also
bring OKRs that you've written and ask
the GPT to refine them for you. Like
these are specific examples, but every
company has maybe hundreds if not
thousands of potential use cases for for
these custom GPTs, custom solutions, and
it really it really just reverse
engineers to where you can make the most
impact. Yeah. Are there problems or use
cases that require a custom solution
where a GPT is just not
I guess good enough and you need to
build custom software and how do you
make that decision?
So yeah, I mean like this conversation
is really focused on custom GPTs but
like one thing that we have had a little
bit of a struggle with is when you're
training a custom GPT you're training it
on external data, right? you're training
it on data that OpenAI just doesn't have
access to today through their general
purpose models. That's that's the
benefit of a custom GPT. Two ways to
train a custom GPT. One is through
static knowledge documents that you you
know create a PDF, put it in the GPT,
tell the GPT, you know, here's what's in
here's what's in this document. Here's
when you're going to use and reference
this document. Another way is by
creating an API connection, establishing
an API connection into a thirdparty
source via the actions feature in GPTs.
So, we've done a lot of that. Like,
we've done a lot of experimentation with
that actions feature doesn't always work
as well as advertised. Sometimes we're
blowing through context window
limitations in the GPTs, which are much
smaller than if you're building on the
OpenAI API. Sometimes APIs are just not
structured in a way that's useful for
the GPT. So yeah, like there those are
when when
I kind of like maybe simplify this by
saying if you want a dynamic data pull
most of the time, not all of the time,
like sometimes the GBC are good at this,
but most of the time you might need some
kind of like more robust custom solution
outside of a GBT. Maybe at that point
you're developing on top of one of the
APIs, the frontier APIs. Gotcha. um how
do you make sure the work that you and
your organization
um are doing has a measurable business
impact? How how do you talk about the
ROI of this transformation? Yeah, I
think ROI is actually pretty important.
Um there are other characters like me,
you know, running like AI programs that
say like, you know, I need to measure
ROI because it's obvious like everyone's
going to get like massive return on
this. I think I think it's actually
important to measure ROI uh for two
reasons. One, at least two reasons. One
is we want to be able to tell our
executives, you know, and our boards
this is, you know, we're spending all
this money and this is the return that
we're getting out of this, right? So, I
think there's just like fiscal some
fiscal responsibility and and making
sure that you're making uh good
investments. I think the second reason
is in going through that exercise, you
can actually start to prioritize which
projects are we getting the most value
out of maybe double down on those
projects or maybe you create projects
like that in another part of the
business to continue to get high return
on investment. So how do we do that at
user testing? I think it depends on the
project and a lot of times this is
actually connected to custom GPTs but
there are certainly some of these
projects some of these custom GPTs we
will look at the before and after state.
So the before state is it took us this
long to do this thing. This is the level
of quality. This is the level of rigor.
Um you know for example you might be
creating a GPT to augment marketing
campaigns. You're not only making those
marketing campaigns better but you could
probably do more of them because you're
instilling a lot of efficiency in the
process. So we've done that as well,
right? So like there's a before and
after state. The before state is this is
what that looks like in the business
today. The after state is now we're
creating marketing campaigns where we're
getting better returns on and we can do
more of these. We know what the average
value is per campaign. So if we can
increase that by 30%. You know then we
have a pretty good calculation of what
that return is. Um so this is these are
kind of like the this is kind of like
the modeling that we do for a lot of the
projects that we work on here at user
testing. Yeah. uh we talked about how
you've been um enabling AI adoption
across the organization. Are there
particular business units or functional
units where the use cases are more
prevalent or impactful or have the the
biggest ROI?
I think yeah there's probably two areas
of the business that are most meaningful
to us right now. I would say this like I
think the caveat here is like there's
probably no part of our business that
doesn't get massive return by doing this
stuff right but I think the two areas of
our business where we probably get it
feels like the lowest hanging fruit on
on return on investment is one sales
right go to market we want to be able to
sell you know more software retain more
customers and there's a lot of
opportunities for us to bring AI into
the process to help us do that right so
that's an obvious one I think the second
one is how do we use AI tools tools to
increase rigor and efficiency when we're
writing code. We're a software company,
right? So, we're building a technical
product. And the more we can enhance
that process, the more product that we
can ship, the better our products
become. Like probably for most SAS
businesses, like those are that that
that's like the the lowhanging fruit.
Yeah. Uh can we talk a little bit about
efficiency? For a lot of people,
efficiency is code for fewer people in
the future. How do you think about
efficiency and AI and the future of
workforce?
Yeah. So, I think this is probably going
to look different for every company. I
can tell you how we look at it here at
user testing is certainly by
integrating AI capabilities into you
know your workflows and your process of
of conducting work you create greater
efficiencies right you could save
yourself maybe it's 12 hours a week
maybe it's 3 days a week whatever that
is so then the question becomes is what
do you replace with that time are you
reducing headcount and just doing the
same level of work with less people
that's not that interesting to us I
think we're far more interested
interested in doing more with more,
right? So, like, okay, everybody saves
12 hours of their week. Now, we can
focus on other areas of the business,
other challenges. You know, we're just
better positioned to create a better
company by being able to do more. And I
think that is by far the most
interesting way that AI impacts our
business is we can do more with more.
as we come to a close, I'd love to ask
some um recommendation related questions
based on your own experience. And so I
guess firstly for leaders who are
starting to embed AI in their teams
today, what's the first step that you'd
recommend?
I think the first step is to figure out
who's going to lead that that effort in
your organization. Um this is not the
side gig of a half a dozen people in
your company. I mean maybe maybe if your
company's a half a dozen people maybe it
is right but like if you've got at least
maybe like two 300 people in your
company you want to appoint somebody
that this is going to be their dedicated
mission um and that person uh I talked
about this a lot like that person has
four key characteristics one is they're
fluent in AI tools that seems like an
obvious one right like you want to
somebody that's going to understand what
the capabilities are and make sure we
understand how those capabilities
connect to the business I think the
second thing is this person knows enough
about the business that they kind of
understand how it all comes together,
right? You're not an expert in HR, but
you understand what HR does. You're not
an expert marketing, but you know what
marketing does, right? So, a person that
understands and knows enough to be
dangerous around all functions of the
business. The third relatively obvious
one, they know how to get stuff done,
right? Like anytime we ask somebody to
lead something something important, they
should be someone that knows how to get
stuff done. The fourth characteristic I
think is the least obvious and most
important and these are deeply creative
individuals. The reason why that's
important is because we've never
deployed a technology like generative AI
in our businesses before, right? It's
it's a pretty abstract technology. It is
not like deploying a CRM like
Salesforce, right? When you're deploying
Salesforce, you're going to teach your
users to push that button, pull that
lever, get that output, that output
every time. Every time you push that
button, you're going to get that output.
With generative AI, it's very different.
It's very abstract, and you need someone
that's going to be able to think
creatively about how to translate that
abstract layer into something that feels
real and tangible for people across the
company. Does that creat that creativity
suggest they come from a particular part
of the organization or are there ways to
I don't know evaluate the creativity of
a I'm just picking some random business
units a finance person HR person
I don't know is is the answer to that
question like I'm not really sure I I
can tell you this um yeah like it could
be a finance person sure like it could
be the CTO it could be uh it could be
anyone in the company. Uh I don't think
that
the AI transformation lead comes from
any one specific discipline. Like there
are creative individuals across all
different roles in a company. And by the
way, in business we have a a term for
this creativity in business. Typically
we call them entrepreneurs. Like
entrepreneurs is really a different way
of saying someone that thinks really
creatively about business application.
And usually they think so creatively
about it that they go and create
something, right? like they create
something out of nothing. I would Yeah.
Like if you're looking for who are the
individuals that might possibly be
really creative enough to be able to
handle this, it might be people with an
entrepreneurial background. Um, you
know, maybe I don't know, maybe they do
like woodworking on their weekends,
right? Like that's a creative activity.
I don't think there's like really like a
paradigm like that you can follow to say
like, okay, like if we if we look at all
these different variables, like that's
going to lead us to this person. I I
think you just have to to be be a little
bit creative, right? Like be a little
bit creative about who that creative
person is. What's the role of the
founder
or CEO in a transformation like this?
I guess founder implies like more early
stage. I think yeah CEO look at at the
end of the day your AI transformation is
a top down bottom up approach and we
talked about different ways that that
happens. Uh the top neither is
negotiable, right? You have to have
both. And I think the top down approach,
it's super important for a CEO to
regularly communicate with the
organization uh about why you're doing
this, about how you're doing this, like
how important this is to the company
that we actually move through some kind
of transformation and embrace this. The
CEO is going to set the tone. Um you
know, like you're asking that question
and I immediately think about the
internal Shopify memo that like was
pretty aggressive, right? like that was
a pretty aggressive memo that came from
the CEO. And I think when I first read
that, I um I had like a negative
reaction to it, but then I like stopped
and I read it again and I thought like
actually agree with like pretty much
everything that the CEO is saying. Um
but the tone of that memo was a little
bit too harsh, right? So like I think a
CEO is really important to one say
here's what we're doing, here's why
we're doing it, but be able to deliver
that in a way that inspires the
organization to follow the mission. How
should the CEO be using Gen AI
themselves? And I'm especially
interested in CEOs who are non-technical
like Toby obviously technical likely to
be playing around with new technologies
all the time, but many CEOs are are not
technical. what what role should AI play
for the CEO and how they do their jobs
and run their business? Yeah, I I don't
I don't think technical versus
nontechnical is like really relevant
here. I think when you're talking about
a CEO, that's a strategic person, right?
That's that's a person that is setting
the strategy and the direction of the
company. That's that's maybe the most
high value use case for for AI.
Generally, in a business filled with
knowledge workers, you use AI in three
ways. You use it as an intern, you use
it as an assistant, and you use it as a
thought partner. You know, like the
intern use cases and the assistant use
cases are kind of like the lower level,
but still very valuable use cases, but
there is no use case that nearly touches
the value of using it as a thought
partner. We see CEOs that are uh, you
know, using AI to help prepare for their
board meetings, help write their board
letters, right? That those are great use
cases for AI. You're using it as a
strategic partner. you're using it to
say, "Here's how I'm thinking about this
specific strategy in our organization.
What are my blind spots? What are the
other things that I should be doing? Um,
you know, help me understand, you know,
how to think about this." It may be an
even even more strategic layer or like,
"Hey, I'm going to go in front of my
board next week. Here's our board deck.
What are what holes are they going to
poke in our strategy? What questions
should I be prepared for?" By the way, I
think everyone in the company should be
using it for those like those types of
use cases. But yeah, like especially a
CEO, a CEO is probably not going to like
use AI every day to write their emails,
but they are they should be using it
pretty regularly to again be a thought
partner.
Last question.
Do you think AI adoption will become a
competitive differentiator or do you
think it ultimately becomes table stakes
for every organization or both? I think
it's both and I think it's both today.
Um,
to me it feels like table stakes. Uh, it
feels like, you know, every company I
think has really turned the corner on
recognizing how important this is and
how important it is to like really start
transforming the way that we work around
AI capabilities. Um, so yeah, like not
every company has done this though,
right? Like not every company has even
taken the first steps to do this. And if
you have taken steps and if you're
moving your way through that
transformation, I do definitely think
that is a differentiator.
Awesome. Michael, I really appreciate
you coming by. Just curious and sharing
your perspectives from helping user
testing
um enable a top down and bottoms up uh
AI program. And uh I wish you the best
of luck. Thanks, D. It was great to chat
with you.

cleanText:
Today I'm just curious.
I'm joined by Michael Domanic, Head of Generative AI Business Strategy at UserTesting, the world's leading on-demand human insights platform.
Michael leads the company's internal AI transformation program, embedding AI into workflows across every function.
He spent years building conversational AI and now focuses on making generative AI not just practical but measurable.
Today we'll explore how he's doing that and what others can learn from his hands-on experience leading change at scale.
Michael, welcome to Just Curious.
Thanks D.
It's great to be here.
You've worked across customer experience strategy and now AI transformation.
Tell us a little bit about that journey that brought you to leading AI transformation at UserTesting.
Yeah.
So I mean the journey actually starts before I was actually at UserTesting.
I used to be a customer of UserTesting.
So, during chatbot pipe cycle 1.0, which is what I call it.
So that's takes us to the period of like 2016 to 2019, 2020.
Um, I was designing a lot of conversational interface experiences.
Um, in that era, every brand wanted a Facebook messenger chatbot.
Um, or later that became Slack bots, Skype bots.
The backdrop to all of that was conversational interface was proliferating in homes across America via Alexa and Google Assistant and Google Home.
So I actually used to work um with companies designing those experiences and used to test it at UserTesting.
Joined UserTesting, have had a lot of different roles in the organization.
And in November of 2022 when OpenAI launched, you know, Transformer 3.5, like that felt to me like we were kind of going back to that moment that I was in before UserTesting, albeit with much better technology.
So, it just really felt like the time for our company to wrap our arms around this, embrace it.
I had a lot of support from leadership to really push that mission forward.
Can you tell us a little bit more about UserTesting and why is AI so important to the future of the business?
Yeah, so UserTesting is a platform that our customers use to create great experiences for their customers, right?
So a lot of times our platform is getting used by designers, by UX researchers, but also by folks from marketing that want to test, you know, their marketing campaigns, copy, images, you know, all that stuff.
Um, and you know, I think when it comes to AI at UserTesting, there's two really important ways that we use AI here.
So, one is the mission that I'm attached to, which is to transform our organization, transform the way that we work by embracing AI capabilities.
And the second way that we really use AI is in our product, right?
So like we're designing a lot of features within our product that make it easier for our customers to use our product, enhance the value that they get from our product by leveraging AI capabilities.
The thing that I'm mostly focused on is the internal transformation thing.
That's is that's super important for UserTesting and I think it's important for any company with a focus on knowledge work because we know how much the current AI capabilities can enhance the work that you're doing, create amazing efficiencies, help you create work faster and really increase the strategy.
So we know that's a possibility UserTesting.
So we're really again wrapping our arms around this and embracing those capabilities.
Many companies struggle to move past curiosity into implementation.
What were the first time?
What were the first signs rather at UserTesting that it was time to invest in a true AI transformation effort?
Yeah, it's a great question.
You know, I mentioned those two missions that we have to embrace AI and UserTesting.
One in our product and you know, one to transform the organization.
I think for us early on, we initially set out to integrate AI into our product.
We had already been doing this right even before the generative AI boom.
We've been building machine learning homegrown machine learning models since 2019 and putting that in our product.
So again it just felt very natural to us when this you know these generative AI capabilities uh became available to businesses to build upon that felt very natural.
Now the internal stuff we had had a lot of conversations for probably a period of about six to maybe 10 months call it we had a lot of internal conversations but like most organizations we were trying to figure out how does this integrate right like how do how do we actually use this to augment what we're doing.
Um, I think in those early days for me it was kind of crucial to focus in on a specific use case and um the use case that I focused on non on is a problem that we dealt with and pretty much every other company deals with and that's the problem of information fragmentation.
So we have all of this information um that gets disseminated across the organization and it's in a lot of different places.
You know our sales team uses Highspot, the rest of the company uses Confluence.
There's other repositories of knowledge.
I did an internal study that looked at the cost of the problem and we were just losing way too much time because people were just hunting through all of the different resources, you know, knowledge repositories that we have to find answers to simple questions.
So actually what I did was in those early days is created a custom GPT that pulled all those knowledge resources together and did another study that showed how much of an improvement that was.
And it was really clear to us at that time that we were saving a ton of time in you know folks trying to find answers to questions.
We were also increasing the access to knowledge for folks.
So in those early days that study that experiment that we did made it really clear what the possibility was throughout the rest of the organization.
What internal challenges do you face early on either culturally or operationally and how did you start to overcome them?
Yeah, I I think we kind of face both challenges, both cultural and operational.
I think the the cultural stuff is probably stuff that like every organization was dealing with, continues to deal with.
I think a lot of that has to do with people's trepidation about this, you know, proliferation of AI.
I make it really clear to our organization that I think the genie is out of the bottle when it like that genie is not going back in.
I think we're all going to get face this transformation sooner or later, probably sooner than later.
And I think it's the responsibility of any employer that considers themselves a good employer to really uh lead their organization through this transformation, provide them with the tools, the training um then enablement to be able to take that that transformation on.
I think that's a really important part of our mission and again this is something I talk to our organization about quite often.
I think operational challenges like this is a we're asking people to change a lot of their behavior, right?
I think that's what successful transformation looks like when it comes to AI and that's a hard thing to do.
Changing changing behavior is a really hard thing to do for us.
Once we decided that we were going to make investments here, we chose to use enterprise chatbt as our center of gravity general purpose solution.
Uh we were deliberate about who we rolled that out to in the early days.
So it wasn't full enterprise at that time.
We handpicked individuals who we knew were going to be our early adopters who were going to talk about the interesting things that they were doing and that like to be a pretty good strategy for us because it created a little bit of virality.
Um it created a little bit of FOMO for the individuals who didn't have access.
They were like you know why does this person get access to this transformational tool and I don't right.
So that that kind of helped us um really like make this thing a little bit viral within the company.
Um, a few months later we went, you know, wall-to-wall enterprise.
That was in the summer of 2024.
And by that point, you know, a lot of that interest had been built up in the organization.
So from an operational standpoint, you know, a couple months into our deployment, people a lot of people in the organization felt like they were ready to start experimenting.
Yeah.
And when you picked those early adopters, did you reach out to people you thought had the potential to be kind of early testers?
Did you did you pick a certain number of people within each business or functional unit?
What what did that look like?
Yeah, I think there were a couple things.
So, one is that this conversation had already been playing out in pockets of the organization.
So we were aware of where that conversation was happening, who the players were that were involved in that conversation.
You know, the these were individuals who conveyed a specific like specific interest in in doing this.
So that was kind of like one way that we identified who those early adopters were.
Another way is very early on in our chat GPT deployment, we were invited to OpenAI to do a hackathon, a GPT hackathon.
And then again like we kind of handpicked a larger set of individuals to participate in that.
And again like that showed us who was really leaning in, who who was really interested in experimenting.
So that was another kind of wave of early adopters.
And then from that point some you know awareness had kind of spread in the organization some virality had spread through the organization and a lot of other people were saying like hey like I've been reading a lot about this I have my own personal account maybe I've been using it for work maybe I haven't not going to tell you right but I would love to use it for work and uh you know again that was like another maybe another wave of that that those early adopters and maybe by that point enough of the organization had kind of realized that people that I work with are doing really interesting things.
I want to do those interesting things, too.
So, this interest kind of kept compounding over time.
You mentioned virality.
Were there any things that you did to help facilitate virality and the sharing of what people were doing within the broader organization?
Yeah, we talked about this a lot in those days.
I mean we still do but you know what we did was in lunch and learns or at all hands meetings you know anytime a large kind of cross-section of the organization was getting together we were talking about the things that the early adopters were doing some of the experiments that they were running some of the you know those early days like the GPTs that folks were creating so yeah this was something that we talked about to try to spread some of that interest and and and that virality.
Yeah.
In terms of how they were using it, did you shape that use at all with the early adopters?
Did you allow them to freestyle based on how they were using it already and maybe what problems they saw it could be helpful to solving for them?
How did that how did that use kind of manifest itself?
I think it was both things that you mentioned.
You know, we had spent a lot of time thinking about what are the really interesting ways, the meaningful ways that we could bring this into our organization.
Um, as we identified those interesting use cases, sure, we shared that out with our early adopters and saying like, "Hey, try this or try this."
Folks were also doing a lot of experiments, right?
They were figuring out other interesting things to do with the tool.
So, there was a lot of knowledge sharing that helped other people figure out like, hey, like this person's doing this.
I might not do that exact thing, but that gives me an idea over here.
I think the genesis of this is really to spur on that conversation that was happening in places like a dedicated slack channel.
At that at that point, it was like our AI experimenters Slack channel.
We were getting together regularly as a group, an early adopters group to, you know, again have these conversations, talk about the interesting things that we're doing, the interesting things that we're learning, how are the models changing, how do those changes impact other things that we might be able to do.
Yeah.
Uh you mentioned that early adopters and then I guess some of the later adopters were actively experimenting.
Somewhere building GPTs and sharing them with the organization.
Uh sounds like a very kind of bottoms up effort.
Uh was there a top-down strategy that you then layered on?
Um and yeah, tell us a little bit more about that.
When did you decide to um you know layer on a top down strategy?
What did it look like and how did that play out?
Yeah, I think I think that top down strategy actually came first.
So in those again early days with the top down strategy, the first thing that was established here at UserTesting was an AI working group, an AI governance group where we had identified what are the possibilities with these tools, right?
Like just a cross functional group people, leaders from around the organization having a conversation about what are the what are the possibilities here?
What's the art of the possible?
Um then that quickly turned into what are the security implications?
What are the legal implications?
Do we create an AI usage guideline?
Do we create an internal AI manifesto about uh what do we do with the tools?
How do we use it?
Why are we doing this?
So yes, I mean like that is that is all stuff that was kind of happening in the very very early days I think before we even rolled out any general purpose tools.
Um and then once we felt like we were ready to roll those tools out because we had some basic infrastructure in place um you know then then that's when we kind of went out to our early adopters and said you have access to this tool now you know you're one of our early adopters you're one of our champions you know let's figure out how how we use this.
What did that initial governance look like and what was your approach to balancing innovation and experimentation with legal or ethical or security concerns?
So yeah and like I said the early governance was a cross functional group of people.
So people from legal security, uh our CEO, our CTO, leaders from product, leaders from engineering, like basically like any part of the organization that we felt like was going to get impacted by this transformation um had a seat at the table and still do like that's still a group that exists and we still meet on a very regular basis.
In those early days, it was super important for us to figure out what are those legal and security implications.
So the security implications pretty obvious, right?
If we're using this tool, if we're putting sensitive data, company data into this tool, is that going to show up in the response of somebody's prompt outside of our company, right?
Like we didn't want that to get leaked.
So, we worked with our partners to make sure that we were operating in an environment that our data, our prompts, everything that we're doing doesn't train the model.
Think obviously like that's really important for probably most if not all businesses.
I think when we in those early days as well, the other thing that's really important was important for us to figure out was you know there's people across our organization that have access to all sorts of sensitive data.
What data is a no


What data can we not use in any AI context, and what data can we be more liberal about? UserTesting has, I would say, a relatively cautiously liberal AI governance policy. There are definitely classes of data that no one can ever use in a context of AI, and a lot of that is our customer data. So, earlier, I talked about how our customers use UserTesting. They capture feedback on, you know, what it's essentially what it's like to be their customer. Maybe they're designing a new mobile application, and they have a Figma prototype. They're getting feedback on that Figma prototype via our platform. They own all of that, right? Like our customers own all of that data. Very few people in the organization would even have access to that data. And for those that do, they know, and I remind them about this every single day: no customer data could ever be used in an AI context. Unless that's in our product, unless we have agreements, you know, with our customers, they invoke it, right? Like that's something separate. But when you're using LLMs on a day-to-day basis, you're just never going to use that data. There are other like classes of data as well, like PII, obviously, like you don't want to use that. Don't put your credit card in, right? Like don't put employee names and addresses, like stuff like that. But I think every organization needs to figure out what their data strategy is and make sure that that gets clearly and regularly communicated throughout the company, right? You mentioned the building of custom GPTs. I guess a first step is identifying a use case or a problem to solve. What do you look for when you are looking for a good use case for AI?

That is a great question. So that's not always me making that decision. We have fully democratized the building of custom GPTs throughout the organization. You know, we talk about this a lot in the company. We create GPTs that are, you know, intended to be used by essentially everyone in the company. And everyone in the company has the ability to create them. They don't need to come to me and say, like, hey, like I want to do this thing with custom GPTs. Is it okay if I do this? Right? As long as it fits into, you know, our governance policies, like that's totally fine. Like create a custom GPT. I think like the larger question might be what are custom GPTs good at and like what should companies be thinking about using them for? I think like GPTs are really great at any kind of repetitive workflow that you might be doing. I'll give you an example. Like I have a GPT that analyzes our usage and adoption for all of our AI tools, right? I get that from the vendor. It's often like a massive data dump that they give to me that I have to like sift through, but I've created a custom GPT that analyzes all of that, spits out reports. I send those reports to leaders in the organization. They can see what their teams are doing, right? Like that's a great use case for a GPT. Um, and that's just it's just me using that GPT. Yeah, other use cases for GPTs that are, you know, used across our organization is we have one that creates OKRs for everyone in the company. Um, you know, I don't want anyone in our company to have to spend the time to write really great OKRs. Like, you shouldn't have to be good at writing OKRs. That's a distraction from the thing that you're hired at. Like, if you're a salesperson, you're hired because you're a great salesperson, not because you're great at writing OKRs, right? I want you to have great OKRs. Like I want you to have like a really awesome road map that matters to the larger goals of the organization, but you certainly don't need to be good at creating them, and that's what that GPT does, right? That GPT is trained on here are the large goals of the organization, here's our executive goals, senior leadership team, you know, middle management, and then individual contributors. So wherever you sit in the organization, the GPT already knows what are the goals for essentially everyone above you in this company. Tell us what you're working on. Okay, here's a great set of OKRs for you. You could also bring OKRs that you've written and ask the GPT to refine them for you. Like these are specific examples, but every company has maybe hundreds if not thousands of potential use cases for these custom GPTs, custom solutions, and it really, it really just reverse engineers to where you can make the most impact. Yeah. Are there problems or use cases that require a custom solution where a GPT is just not, I guess, good enough, and you need to build custom software, and how do you make that decision?

So yeah, I mean, like this conversation is really focused on custom GPTs, but like one thing that we have had a little bit of a struggle with is when you're training a custom GPT, you're training it on external data, right? You're training it on data that OpenAI just doesn't have access to today through their general purpose models. That's the benefit of a custom GPT. Two ways to train a custom GPT. One is through static knowledge documents that you, you know, create a PDF, put it in the GPT, tell the GPT, you know, here's what's in, here's what's in this document. Here's when you're going to use and reference this document. Another way is by creating an API connection, establishing an API connection into a third-party source via the actions feature in GPTs. So, we've done a lot of that. Like, we've done a lot of experimentation with that. Actions feature doesn't always work as well as advertised. Sometimes we're blowing through context window limitations in the GPTs, which are much smaller than if you're building on the OpenAI API. Sometimes APIs are just not structured in a way that's useful for the GPT. So yeah, like there, those are when, when I kind of like maybe simplify this by saying if you want a dynamic data pull most of the time, not all of the time, like sometimes the GPTs are good at this, but most of the time you might need some kind of like more robust custom solution outside of a GPT. Maybe at that point you're developing on top of one of the APIs, the frontier APIs. Gotcha. Um, how do you make sure the work that you and your organization are doing has a measurable business impact? How, how do you talk about the ROI of this transformation? Yeah, I think ROI is actually pretty important. Um, there are other characters like me, you know, running like AI programs that say, like, you know, I need to measure ROI because it's obvious, like everyone's going to get like massive return on this. I think, I think it's actually important to measure ROI for two reasons. One, at least two reasons. One is we want to be able to tell our executives, you know, and our boards, this is, you know, we're spending all this money, and this is the return that we're getting out of this, right? So, I think there's just like fiscal, some fiscal responsibility and and making sure that you're making good investments. I think the second reason is in going through that exercise, you can actually start to prioritize which projects are we getting the most value out of, maybe double down on those projects, or maybe you create projects like that in another part of the business to continue to get high return on investment. So how do we do that at UserTesting? I think it depends on the project, and a lot of times this is actually connected to custom GPTs, but there are certainly some of these projects, some of these custom GPTs, we will look at the before and after state. So the before state is it took us this long to do this thing. This is the level of quality. This is the level of rigor. Um, you know, for example, you might be creating a GPT to augment marketing campaigns. You're not only making those marketing campaigns better, but you could probably do more of them because you're instilling a lot of efficiency in the process. So we've done that as well, right? So like there's a before and after state. The before state is this is what that looks like in the business today. The after state is now we're creating marketing campaigns where we're getting better returns on, and we can do more of these. We know what the average value is per campaign. So if we can increase that by 30%, you know, then we have a pretty good calculation of what that return is. Um, so this is these are kind of like the, this is kind of like the modeling that we do for a lot of the projects that we work on here at UserTesting. Yeah. Uh, we talked about how you've been enabling AI adoption across the organization. Are there particular business units or functional units where the use cases are more prevalent or impactful or have the biggest ROI?

I think yeah, there's probably two areas of the business that are most meaningful to us right now. I would say this, like I think the caveat here is like there's probably no part of our business that doesn't get massive return by doing this stuff, right? But I think the two areas of our business where we probably get, it feels like the lowest hanging fruit on return on investment is one, sales, right? Go to market, we want to be able to sell, you know, more software, retain more customers, and there's a lot of opportunities for us to bring AI into the process to help us do that, right? So that's an obvious one. I think the second one is how do we use AI tools to increase rigor and efficiency when we're writing code? We're a software company, right? So, we're building a technical product. And the more we can enhance that process, the more product that we can ship, the better our products become. Like probably for most SaaS businesses, like those are that that that's like the the low-hanging fruit. Yeah. Uh, can we talk a little bit about efficiency? For a lot of people, efficiency is code for fewer people in the future. How do you think about efficiency and AI and the future of workforce?

Yeah. So, I think this is probably going to look different for every company. I can tell you how we look at it here at UserTesting is certainly by integrating AI capabilities into, you know, your workflows and your process of conducting work, you create greater efficiencies, right? You could save yourself, maybe it's 12 hours a week, maybe it's 3 days a week, whatever that is. So then the question becomes is what do you replace with that time? Are you reducing headcount and just doing the same level of work with less people? That's not that interesting to us. I think we're far more interested in doing more with more, right? So, like, okay, everybody saves 12 hours of their week. Now, we can focus on other areas of the business, other challenges. You know, we're just better positioned to create a better company by being able to do more. And I think that is by far the most interesting way that AI impacts our business is we can do more with more.
As we come to a close, I'd love to ask some recommendation-related questions based on your own experience. And so I guess, firstly, for leaders who are starting to embed AI in their teams today, what's the first step that you'd recommend?

I think the first step is to figure out who's going to lead that effort in your organization. Um, this is not the side gig of a half a dozen people in your company. I mean, maybe, maybe if your company's a half a dozen people, maybe it is, right? But like if you've got at least maybe like two, 300 people in your company, you want to appoint somebody that this is going to be their dedicated mission. Um, and that person, uh, I talked about this a lot, like that person has four key characteristics. One is they're fluent in AI tools. That seems like an obvious one, right? Like you want to somebody that's going to understand what the capabilities are and make sure we understand how those capabilities connect to the business. I think the second thing is this person knows enough about the business that they kind of understand how it all comes together, right? You're not an expert in HR, but you understand what HR does. You're not an expert in marketing, but you know what marketing does, right? So, a person that understands and knows enough to be dangerous around all functions of the business. The third, relatively obvious one, they know how to get stuff done, right? Like anytime we ask somebody to lead something, something important, they should be someone that knows how to get stuff done. The fourth characteristic, I think, is the least obvious and most important, and these are deeply creative individuals. The reason why that's important is because we've never deployed a technology like generative AI in our businesses before, right? It's it's a pretty abstract technology. It is not like deploying a CRM like Salesforce, right? When you're deploying Salesforce, you're going to teach your users to push that button, pull that lever, get that output, that output every time. Every time you push that button, you're going to get that output. With generative AI, it's very different. It's very abstract, and you need someone that's going to be able to think creatively about how to translate that abstract layer into something that feels real and tangible for people across the company. Does that create, that creativity suggest they come from a particular part of the organization, or are there ways to, I don't know, evaluate the creativity of a, I'm just picking some random business units, a finance person, HR person, I don't know, is, is the answer to that question, like, I'm not really sure? I, I can tell you this, um, yeah, like it could be a finance person, sure, like it could be the CTO, it could be, uh, it could be anyone in the company. Uh, I don't think that the AI transformation lead comes from any one specific discipline. Like there are creative individuals across all different roles in a company. And by the way, in business, we have a term for this creativity in business. Typically, we call them entrepreneurs. Like entrepreneurs is really a different way of saying someone that thinks really creatively about business application. And usually they think so creatively about it that they go and create something, right? Like they create something out of nothing. I would, yeah. Like if you're looking for who are the individuals that might possibly be really creative enough to be able to handle this, it might be people with an entrepreneurial background. Um, you know, maybe, I don't know, maybe they do like woodworking on their weekends, right? Like that's a creative activity. I don't think there's like really like a paradigm like that you can follow to say, like, okay, like if we, if we look at all these different variables, like that's going to lead us to this person. Generally, in a business filled with knowledge workers, you use AI in three ways.
You use it as an intern, you use it as an assistant, and you use it as a thought partner.
